abstract.p: Antony Sher falls victim to throat infection while starring in Royal Shakespeare Co performance of Shakespeare's Macbeth in New Haven as part of International Festival of Arts & Ideas; is replaced by understudy after intoning line 'We shall speak no more;' Museum for African Art and Studio Museum plan exhibition focusing on 1,000 years of beaded arts among Yoruba-speaking peoples of Nigeria, Cuba, Brazil and United States; Pete Seeger and Tao Rodriguez plan free concert to open Hudson River Festival, series of music, dance, art and puppetry events; J Paul Getty Museum, Los Angeles, plans exhibition of Paris street photographs, 1897-1927, by Eugene Atget; photos (M)

block.p: Such is the luck that surrounds Shakespeare's ''Macbeth'' that professionals shy from speaking its name, referring to ''the Scottish play.'' The jinx has struck again. Some 20 minutes into a Royal Shakespeare Company performance on Saturday night at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven during the International Festival of Arts & Ideas, Antony Sher, in the title role, intoned the Act I, Scene 5 line ''We shall speak no more.'' And he didn't. Exiting according to stage directions, he did not appear again, falling victim to a throat infection, and was replaced by an understudy, John Killeran. Mr. Sher, who had played more than 150 performances without absence, had problems early Saturday but decided to go on. He is expected to return tonight.

In the first collaboration between the Museum for African Art in SoHo and the Studio Museum in Harlem, 1,000 years of beaded arts among the Yoruba-speaking peoples of Nigeria, Cuba, Brazil and the United States are to be exhibited beginning tomorrow. With thrones and necklaces commissioned for African royalty and ceremonial coronets and divination beads used in Yoruba worship, ''Beads, Body, and Soul: Art and Light in the Yoruba Universe'' features more than 150 objects, focusing in SoHo through Aug. 27 on bead culture from the 11th to the 19th century and in Harlem through Sept. 17 on the 19th century to the present.

A free concert by Pete Seeger and his grandson Tao Rodriguez at 7 tonight at the World Financial Center Plaza at Liberty Street and the Hudson River ushers in the Hudson River Festival, a series of music, dance, art and puppetry events with international attractions through Aug. 31 at sites in the center as well as along Battery Park's esplanade and parks.

Through the lens of his heavy tripod-mounted camera, Eugene Atget (1856-1927) collected a Paris seldom seen by tourists and little known to the affluent -- its sidewalk displays, its shop windows and staircases, its sculptures and gardens, its ragpickers and children at play. Of his 8,500 images, more than 80, from about 1897 until his death, go on view from today through Oct. 8 at the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles. Providing context for ''The Man in the Street: Eugene Atget in Paris'' are images by his predecessors Silas A. Holmes in New York and Charles Marville in Paris and successors like Berenice Abbott in New York, Walker Evans in New Orleans and Garry Winogrand in Los Angeles.
